definitions.definition: To be so presumptuous as (to do something) without proper authority or permission [ with to ( + infinitive ) ].
examples: I don't want to pretend to be an authority on this line of business, so I would never presume to tell you how to run your own company.

definitions.definition: To perform , do (something) without authority ; to lay claim to without permission .
examples: Don't make the decision yourself and presume too much.

definitions.definition: To assume or suggest to be true (without proof ); to take for granted , to suppose .
examples: Paw-prints in the snow allow us to presume a visit from next door's cat.

definitions.definition: To take as a premise ; to assume for the sake of argument .
To impose (on) for one's advantage ; to be presumptuous ; to take advantage (of); to take liberties (with) [ with on or upon ].

main_definition: ( transitive ) To be so presumptuous as (to do something) without proper authority or permission [ with to ( + infinitive ) ]. [from 14th c.]
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , now rare ) To perform , do (something) without authority ; to lay claim to without permission . [from 14th c.]
( transitive ) To assume or suggest to be true (without proof ); to take for granted , to suppose . [from 14th c.]
( transitive ) To take as a premise ; to assume for the sake of argument .
( intransitive ) To impose (on) for one's advantage ; to be presumptuous ; to take advantage (of); to take liberties (with) [ with on or upon ]. [from 15th c.]
